title: Conjoined twin baby dies after emergency surgery
text:
O﻿ne of the conjoined twins who were flown from Papua New Guinea to Australia in a desperate attempt to save their lives has died following an emergency surgery.

Tom and Sawong were almost two months old when they were rushed into a seven-hour surgery at ﻿Sydney Children's Hospital on Sunday.﻿

Tom, the most critical of the two, died, while Sawong survived the separation.

READ MORE: ﻿ TPG says possible second death linked to Triple Zero outages

Tom has died after a seven-hour emergency surgery. (Supplied)

Medevac pilot Jurgen Ruh, who has stayed with the family, said the parents were feeling a mixture of sadness and relief.

Sawong is in critical but stable condition and under close intensive care.

He is expected to remain in Sydney for the next few months until the hole in his stomach closes.

"In the first day, he made vast improvements on his medical condition. He is getting better as fast as he can﻿," Ruh told 9news.com.au.

A funeral is being prepared for Tom. ﻿

The brothers were almost two months old when they rushed into the operating room. (Supplied)

The brothers were born attached at the lower abdomen in the remote province of Morobe on October 9 and shared several critical organs, including parts of their liver, bladder and gastrointestinal tract.

Tom also had further issues, including a congenital heart defect and only one kidney. ﻿

Ruh said it was lucky the local hospital could perform the C-section needed to deliver the babies, as only one in 200,000 conjoined twins are born alive.

The brothers were receiving treatment in Port Moresby for several weeks, but the hospital could not perform the separation surgery.

Their parents sought help from Australia, Germany and India.

The conjoined twins were flown to Sydney. (Supplied)

At the time, their father said: ﻿"Tom and Sawong are fighters and have fought since."﻿

The parents were in the process of making arrangements for Germany when Tom's health deteriorated on Thursday, and the twins were rushed to nearby Sydney. ﻿

Specialists from the ﻿Sydney Children's Hospitals Network had helped with the transfer.

Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister James Marape told reporters he was assured that the Australian government would cover the medical bills.

The twins were assessed in Sydney.

Ruh ﻿said specialists believed ﻿Tom had very little chance of surviving their separation. ﻿﻿

title: Glimmer of hope for cheaper domestic air fares
text:
T﻿he consumer watchdog has found domestic air fares surged through October as airlines cashed in on demand during the sports finals season and school holidays.

During the period, NRL and AFL fans from Brisbane flew to Sydney and Melbourne to watch their teams capture grand final victories over Victorian clubs. ﻿

October and late September recorded 5.5 million domestic passengers, according to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's airline report released today.

Brisbane Broncos fans descended on Sydney in October for the NRL grand final (Photo: Steven Siewert) (Sydney Morning Herald)

This was 3.8 per cent higher than last October and the second biggest set of passenger numbers recorded for any month since January 2019, the month when the ACCC first began gathering data on the domestic airline industry.

Qantas and Virgin put on an 45 extra flights to meet the demand, but flights were still fuller than normal.

In October 2025, 84.4 per cent of available seats were filled by passengers, compared with the 12-month average of 81.6 per cent.

ACCC Commissioner Anna Brakey said interstate AFL and NRL teams playing in finals series pushed up air travel demand.

"Airfares are typically elevated during peak demand periods, but the higher passenger levels in October 2025 placed additional pressure on seat capacity which pushed up airfares for consumers," she said.

Qantas and Virgin Australia put on an extra 45 domestic flights during October to meet a surge in demand.. (Getty)

The ACCC research reinforced what many air travellers already know: the aviation market in Australia is heavily concentrated around Qantas and Virgin Australia, with the two airlines holding 98 per cent market share.

But the regulator provided a glimmer of hope for cheaper future air tickets, noting Qantas and Virgin Australia are planning to increase their fleets next year.

This includes Qantas redeploying its 13 Airbus A320 planes from the axed Jetstar Asia carrier.﻿

title: TPG says possible second death linked to Triple Zero outages
text:
TPG Telecom says that it is possible a second death has been linked to the network's ongoing struggles with users attempting to contact Triple Zero on Samsung devices using out-of-date software.

As company representatives appeared before a Senate committee on Triple Zero outages and resilience, TPG said it was working to clarify the circumstances around a person's death in December.

﻿"TPG was made aware on December 8, 2025, that the calls to Triple Zero may have been made in connection with an individual who has lost their life," the telco said in a statement today.

TPG Telecom says that it is possible a second death has been linked to the network's ongoing struggles with users attempting to contact Triple Zero. (Supplied)

"We have sought to clarify the circumstances, but details have not yet been verified by relevant emergency authorities."

TPG said it had provided and would continue to provide information to the Australian Communication and Media Authority (ACMA) regarding the incident.

The failed September contact was made using a Samsung device that was operating out-of-date software.﻿

Some older Samsung phones need software updates to contact triple zero, TPG says. (iStock)

Last month, TPG confirmed a Sydney person had died after a customer on their network was unable to make Triple Zero calls on their Samsung device.

The incident took place on November 13.

The telco has said Samsung had recently identified that certain older devices needed a software update to contact Triple Zero on TPG's mobile network.﻿

Shadow Minister for Communications Melissa McIntosh. (Alex Ellinghausen)

TPG said it had been communicating with affected customers about "urgently" updating their software.

"TPG also continues to urge all customers with outdated software to replace or update their devices without delay to ensure they can reach Triple Zero in an emergency," the company said today.

Shadow Communications Minister Melissa McIntosh called the Triple Zero outages a "public safety risk".

In a release, her office said 71 Samsung mobile devices had been identified as not correctly connecting to Triple Zero in October.

Of those, 11 needed a replacement, and 60 a software update, with 28 days for affected phone users to act.

"I am again urging all Australians with one of these Samsung devices to act on the message they have received to either update their software or get a new device," she said.

"If you have one of the 71 Samsung devices, I urge you to update your software urgently or contact your telco provider."

title: This baby just won a title usually reserved for microbiologists, neuroscientists
text:
A baby has miraculously snagged a spot on the list of most influential people in science for 2025.﻿

Nature Magazine today announced its annual list of 10 people who shaped science and one honouree was not like the others.

Unlike the physicists, geoscientists and biologists that dominated the list, KJ Muldoon is just a little boy from Pennsylvania, US.

Baby KJ Muldoon's illness is so rare it only affects about 1 in 1.3 million people. (Children's Hospital of Philadelphia)

KJ was diagnosed with an incredibly rare, deadly genetic disease﻿ called carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase 1 deficiency shortly after he was born in August 2024.

The "one in a million" ﻿metabolic condition can cause brain damage and death, especially in infants.

About 50 per cent of babies diagnosed with the disease die in early infancy.

Doctors at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia﻿ worked tirelessly to develop a bespoke treatment using CRISPR gene-editing technology in the hopes of saving KJ's life.

The first of three treatment infusions was administered in February, when KJ was about seven months old.

And it seems to have worked.

KJ's parents and siblings were over the moon when the first-of-its-kind treatment started working. (Chloe Dawson/CHOP via AP)

Before long, KJ was gaining weight and thriving.

He became the first patient to successfully receive personalised CRISPR gene editing therapy and, after spending his first 307 days in hospital, was finally able to go home in June.

"He's always smiling," KJ's mum Nicole Aaron told Nature .

Two of KJ's doctors, paediatrician Rebecca Ahrens-Nicklas and cardiologist Kiran Musunuru are now working on clinical trials to help more children.

The other " Nature's 10" honourees included ﻿geoscientist Mengran Du, who took a submersible 9km down into the deep sea to catch the first glimpse of new ecosystems.

Assistant Professor Mengran Du dove 9000m below the ocean's surface in this deep-sea manned submersible. (Billy H.C. Kwok for Nature)

Agricultural researcher Luciano Moreira was lauded for opening a factory that produces mosquitoes infected with a bacteria that helps stop the spread of human diseases.

Microbiologist and immunologist Susan Monarez was celebrated after being fired as head of the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention for standing up to the Trump administration.

title: 'Cities change': Decades-old greyhound track to be torn down
text:
A greyhound racing track that has stood in Sydney's Inner West for almost a century will be demolished to make room for thousands of homes and community sporting grounds.

New South Wales Premier Chris Minns announced today that the Wentworth Park area, which includes the eponymous greyhound racing track, will become the site of 7300 new homes and green spaces.

The track itself﻿ will be demolished when the racing licence of the NSW Greyhound Breeders, Owners and Trainers Association (GBOTA) for the site runs out in late 2027, with the land to be returned to the City of Sydney and converted into sports grounds.

Concept art of the new-look Wentworth Park. (City of Sydney)

"We recognise Wentworth Park holds deep history and meaning for many people, and we know some will be disappointed by this change," Minns said.

"But cities change and we have a responsibility to plan for the future."

The 3.3-hectare Wentworth Park Sporting Complex precinct will be converted into more sports fields and public green space.

The greyhound track will be demolished. (Janie Barrett)

This will allow for rezoning of the surrounding area the government said would in turn allow for 2500 extra homes.

These will be in addition to the 4800 homes already planned or approved nearby, including 2000 at the old Sydney Fish Market site.

In total, the government's current plan for the area involves 7300 new homes.

The track currently hosts 102 race meets a year. (Janie Barrett)

Mirvac has been tapped as the preferred tenderer for the former Fish Market site, with the company to begin building 1400 homes, including 580 student housing units, by early 2027 if planning is approved.﻿

The government has also committed to supporting the transfer of greyhound racing to other tracks, to the tune of a $10 million allocation to the Greyhound Capital Grants Program for track upgrades.

According to GBOTA, the Wentworth Park grounds currently host 102 race meetings a year.

Premier Chris Minns. (Sitthixay Ditthavong)

"The transition of the Wentworth Park Sporting Complex site to new, enhanced open space and community recreation uses is an exciting new chapter that marks the end of an era for inner city greyhound racing that has taken place there since 1932," Gaming and Racing Minister David Harris said.

"The NSW Government continues to support a competitive, responsible and sustainable greyhound racing industry with the highest standards of animal welfare and integrity that balances tradition with community expectations.

"Greyhound racing is a valuable contributor to regional communities supporting thousands of jobs."

title: Snubs and surprises: All the 2026 Golden Globe nominees
text:
This morning, the Golden Globes nominations were unveiled. Were there big surprises?

The snub of Wicked: For Good in the best picture category, for one. There was also a very gratifying nomination of Amy Madigan for her turn as the villain in Weapons . Overall, most of the nominations closely tracked awards predictions.

Also, all the popular TV shows got nominated.

Paul Thomas Anderson's film "One Battle After Another" led the awards charge. (AP)

As is the case every year, the Globes awards categories suffer from the insistence to categorise movies and television shows as either drama or as "musical or comedy." (There are also always a good couple questions each year about who's a "supporting" actor and who's just acting.)

One Battle After Another was considered by awards-watchers to be the lead contender for awards and it did just that.

That film, which stars Leonardo DiCaprio at his most offhandedly brilliant as a hapless revolutionary bumbling into nightmarish political machinations, all while surrounded by fabulous, powerful and troubled women, is currently available for streaming at movie-theater ticket prices.

READ MORE: The Louvre hit by embarrassing new blunder ﻿

Cynthia Erivo as Elphaba Thropp and Ariana Grande as Glinda Upland in Wicked: For Good. (Universal Pictures)

It will return to select IMAX theatres on December 11 for a week; few tickets remain.

The gorgeous Joachim Trier film Sentimental Value , which received multiple nominations, tracks the relationship between a distressed, easily panicked actress and her callous film director father – plus the life of their family's house as well.

In addition to an unbelievable performance by Renate Reinsve in the lead role, the film also has Elle Fanning absolutely nailing the role of an American actress pushed to the levels of her comfort and talent.

Jacob Elordi and Mia Goth as The Creature and Elizabeth in Guillermo del Toro's Frankenstein. (Netflix)

It seems like a lifetime ago, but Sinners was released just back in April and voters remembered its cultural moment and box office success. The Ryan Coogler Jim-Crow-plus-vampires hit neatly mashed up the horrors of the supernatural with the horrors of the very human.

Hamnet and Wicked: For Good , representing polar opposites of the year in film, also had strong showings.

Parents were unsurprised by nominations for KPop Demon Hunters , the soundtrack of their lives since the mega-hit was released on Netflix just (can you believe it!) back in June.

Zoey, from left, Rumi and Mira in a scene from KPop Demon Hunters. (AP)

There was a very important nomination for the very avatar of our age of apprehension: the terrifying clown-witch visage of Aunt Gladys in Weapons .

( One Battle , Weapons , and Sinners are produced, co-produced and/or distributed by Warner Bros Pictures, which currently shares a parent company with CNN.)

Both Severance , the eerie tribute to the awfulness of having to work, and Adolescence , the Netflix mega-smash about a teenager accused of murder, were well-recognised.

Walton Goggins and Amy lou Wood in The White Lotus. (HBO/Supplied)

Pluribus , The Last of Us and The Pitt – all extremely stressful shows, each apocalyptic in their own way, especially about the dire state of the American health care system – performed well too.

The Golden Globes awards show, hosted by comedian Nikki Glaser, will take place on Sunday, January 11, 2026, US time.

title: 'Time to go': Calls for UTS VC to resign after staff no-confidence vote
text:
One of Australia's top universities is facing a historic crisis, with 95 per cent of staff voting no confidence in vice-chancellor Andrew Parfitt as hundreds of staff and subjects face the axe.

The National Tertiary Education Union (NTEU), which ran the vote, said 1,549 of the roughly 4,000 University of Technology Sydney (UTS) staff cast a ballot, with 1,465 expressing no confidence and just 84 expressing confidence.

"In our 35-year history, UTS has never had a staff ballot on confidence in a vice-chancellor until now. That alone speaks to the unprecedented scale of concern," said Dr Hossai Gul, a researcher at UTS and NTEU representative.

" Staff have waited patiently for a year, hoping for reasons to trust leadership again, but instead have experienced further secrecy, deeper fear and worsening harm. "

Andrew Parfitt came under fire earlier this year for being one of five senior executives who spent more than $140,000 on flights, accommodation and food during a trip to the US. (AAP: Bianca De Marchi)

Dr Parfitt was not immediately available for an interview but in a statement a university spokesperson questioned the "integrity" of the vote.

"We will always respect and listen to the views of our staff. However, the integrity of the vote itself is in question given complaints from some staff who tried to vote and found that their email address had already been used," a university spokesperson said.

"We have raised these serious concerns with the NTEU."

The NTEU responded to university management in a letter, saying it would correct any "mistakes" in the vote.

While the vote was run by the NTEU, it was open to all UTS staff, not just NTEU members.

Staff held a rally on Tuesday to announce the vote results amid a year of conflict over the need for job cuts and revelations of expensive executive travel.

Hossai Gul says staff have lost confidence in the vice-chancellor because of a lack of transparency and a collapse in democratic academic governance. (Supplied: Hossai Gul)

The proposed cuts also attracted the attention of state and federal inquiries and regulators, as staff in distress were given stress management advice that included "washing delicates".

"Staff have lost confidence in the vice-chancellor because of a pervasive lack of transparency, a collapse in democratic academic governance, and a year-long process that has caused significant organisational harm," Dr Gul said.

"Instead of reassurance, staff have experienced fear, confusion and exclusion from decisions that define the future of UTS."

University sends executives to US as staff face sack The spending on alumni events in May comes as the university says it needs to sack 400 staff to save $100 million.

The university spokesperson said the NTEU had "chosen to grandstand" rather than find "viable" solutions to the university's financial challenges.

"These tactics are in stark contrast to the approach from staff who have engaged in the change process, gave thoughtful ideas and worked constructively to help find solutions," the spokesperson said.

"Their feedback is influencing the outcomes and next steps."

Mehreen Faruqi says the VC needs to resign. (AAP: Lukas Coch)

Greens deputy leader and higher education spokesperson Mehreen Faruqi, who questioned UTS leaders at a recent Senate inquiry into alleged governance failures, attended the rally and called on the vice-chancellor to resign.

"Today's no-confidence vote makes one thing undeniable: the people who make this university run no longer trust the people who are supposed to lead it," Ms Faruqi said.

" When staff resoundingly reject you, it's time to go. There is no other option but for the VC to resign. "

Sarah Kaine is leading a separate parliamentary inquiry into university governance. (AAP: Bianca De Marchi)

That was echoed by NSW upper house Labor MP Sarah Kaine, who is leading a separate state inquiry into university governance and also attended the rally.

"Given the debacle that has been the change process at UTS, the decent thing to do would be for the VC to resign — remembering that he has been at, or close to the helm, of the university that he claimed was in [financial] crisis," Dr Kaine said.

$7 million spent on consultants

The turmoil at UTS began when management paid consultants KPMG $7 million to design a change management proposal called Operational Sustainability Initiative.

It proposed about 400 academic and professional staff, or roughly 10 per cent of the workforce, be made redundant and roughly 1,100 subjects be scrapped.

"UTS is operating under a deeply concerning power structure where major decisions affecting academic governance, finances, job security, teaching and research, are driven centrally by the vice-chancellor, with others expected simply to comply," Dr Gul said.

University management says mass sackings unavoidable With the university sector in crisis, thousands face losing their jobs as unions blame poor management and students say they've lost hope.

"That is not how a public university should be governed. Staff see no credible vision for the future of UTS."

The university spokesperson said the proposal was necessary to "secure the future of the university", which was spending more than it earned.

"The challenges we are facing, and change, is difficult and emotional, especially for a purpose-driven community like ours," the spokesperson said.

Last month, the university updated its change proposal and said most academic redundancies would now be voluntary and that some of the 1,100 planned subject cuts would not proceed.

Earlier this year, the university proposed about 400 academic and professional staff be made redundant. (ABC News: Monish Nand)

However, staff anger continued to simmer, particularly when a NSW inquiry heard that amid the furore the vice-chancellor was appointed to another five-year term.

"The handling of the vice-chancellor's contract extension is a key example: over a year ago, his term was extended to seven years, without informing staff, without explaining the decision," Dr Gul said.

"While simultaneously telling us UTS is financially unstable and that jobs must go. That contrast has destroyed any remaining trust."

In a statement, the university said the failure to communicate the extension was an oversight.

More than 100 courses suspended at Sydney university The University of Technology Sydney is suspending more than 100 courses as it prepares for a controversial redundancy program to save $100 million dollars.

"In 2024, the UTS Council was mindful of the need for continuity in leadership with the chancellor's term ending in 2025 and proposed extending the vice-chancellor's contract," the spokesperson said.

"It was an oversight that this was not widely communicated at the time."

Dr Kaine said the current governance arrangements "do not pass the pub test, let alone any test of good governance".

UTS said it had increased the representation of staff and students on the council.

"UTS Council has chosen to increase its representation of elected staff and student members above the minimum to support a strong voice in the constitution of its membership," the spokesperson said.

"UTS also has a student council liaison group."

title: Kids in remote towns say social media ban will make isolation worse
text:
As the social media ban for kids edges closer, teenagers in remote and rural communities are worried about becoming even more isolated.

From Wednesday, kids under 16 will no longer be able to use popular social media platforms, like Snapchat, Facebook, Instagram, YouTube, TikTok, Reddit, Kick, X and Twitch.

But for those who aren't always surrounded by kids their own age, socialising may have just become that much harder.

Frankie Andrews, 13, is a state swimming champion and year 7 student enrolled at the Swifts Creek P-12 School.

Swifts Creek is a remote community in Victoria's High Country, almost five hours north-east from Melbourne.

Frankie said the ban coming into place was going to be a big change, and contacting her long-distance friends would not be as easy.

"I think [the ban] is a good idea and that it should be a thing; but maybe the age should be a bit lower, I reckon like maybe under fourteens," Frankie said.

"Just seeing what happens."

She said social media was something to do for people to fill time, and that it kept them up-to-date.

"It's going to be bad not being able to contact friends as easily," Frankie said.

" I reckon there'll be a lot of people arguing against it and that it'll still stay a thing, but people are going to find their way around it eventually. "

Social media a way to maintain family bonds

Lowanna College student Sabrina Glibanovic, 13, has an online community of friends and finds inspiration for her artwork on a range of social media platforms.

The teenager from Yallourn, a regional town in Victoria's Gippsland area, also uses social media to communicate with her mother's family in Vietnam.

"I don't think they fully understand how we use it and how young people use it to connect with the world," she said.

" I go on to social media, and I can find images to recreate … I just struggle a bit with creativity, and some other artists do too and they like having the inspiration there, so they can have ideas help them fuel their mind. "

Sabrina said she used Pinterest, Instagram and TikTok to look at different art.

Sabrina Glibanovic (back left) uses social media to speak with her family in Vietnam. (Supplied: Sabrina Glibanovic)

She said her friends were also concerned about the ban.

"Like all my friends, [social media] is how we communicate to each other and it's how we connect and how we just relate to each other," she said.

"It's going to cut off all my contact with my family from Vietnam.

"I won't be able to communicate as well with my friends and have that connection through like videos and things."

Loading

Isolation impact

With the school holidays around the corner, Sabrina said it would be harder to make plans with her friends.

"I probably won't be able to go out as much because I don't think I have a lot of their numbers, and I won't be able to hang out with them anymore," she said.

"I'll just be really isolated as well."

Sabrina said there were also a lot of learning opportunities on social media.

"On social media you can learn a lot about how the world works and other worldly problems, and just everything that's happening in the world," she said.

"I know for me, I understand how the rest of the world is, and I've got a lot of that information from social media instead of actually like searching it up, I feel like it's a more fun way of learning than just actually researching."

Daswin De Silva says the social media ban is unlikely to stop kids. (Supplied: La Trobe University)

Doubts about ban's effectiveness

The federal government has put the onus on social media companies to enforce the ban, which comes into effect on December 10.

Social media companies have announced they will use several methods to verify users' age, including having them upload identification, using AI to scan their face and analysing how they use the platforms.

But Latrobe University professor of artificial intelligence (AI) and analytics Daswin De Silva told ABC Gippsland Breakfast he doubted whether the ban would be effective.

"One thing that's clear is that this ban has made kids more innovative and creative thinking outside the box," Professor De Silva said.

" There's been many different methods shared on social platform using a $20 Halloween mask to bypass the facial recognition or a lot of kids moving to new apps that aren't in the ban. "

He said the ban would lead to a "whack-a-mole" approach where children would move to new platforms as existing platforms were banned.

title: Travelling teacher brings instrumental music to regional schools
text:
You can hear Tina Greenfield's classroom from the other side of the school.

It is not because she has rowdy students; in fact, they work together to quickly unpack their instruments, music stands and chairs as they settle in for band practice.

There is always a hum of excitement on the days Ms Greenfield comes to town.

The students also gather for band practice after school. (ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside)

She travels between five schools in the North Burnett, inland from Bundaberg, teaching instrumental music and sharing her passion with students who would otherwise miss out.

"Music is for everyone," Ms Greenfield said.

She has been a key part in revitalising the instrumental music program at primary and high schools in the towns of Monto, Mundubbera and Gayndah.

The program is available to students in year 3 and above. (ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside)

"When I first started out here at the beginning of the year, I put out a note saying, 'Any children that are interested, we'll get them in,'" Ms Greenfield said.

"Everyone has equal opportunity to join the program."

About 80 students across the five schools are now learning percussion, brass and woodwind instruments.

Tina Greenfield teaches 82 students in the North Burnett. (ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside)

Embraced by students

Ms Greenfield said the benefits of music flowed into other classrooms.

"The biggest thing is we can really help foster teamwork … we are an ensemble-based program, so every single child is part of an ensemble," she said.

"It also helps develop their focus.

" My job is to help build that relationship with music so that they've always got a healthy output for their emotions. "

Those life lessons are already being recognised by the students.

The clarinet is Dusty-Rose Louttit's instrument of choice. (ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside)

"[For] some people who are nervous of performing, sometimes an instrument can get them out there, make them feel more confident," Monto State High School student Dusty-Rose Louttit said.

Fellow student Charlotte Dahtler said she was keen to keep playing flute after graduating.

"I'd like to still do it as a hobby — just as a fun thing to do," she said.

Charlotte Dahtler plans to continue playing flute through high school and after graduating. (ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside)

"It gives you a great experience. It opens you up to different talents that you didn't have before, or you never knew you had."

The program has helped boost music exposure to younger students, such as Joseph Slattery.

Joseph Slattery is enjoying learning percussion. (ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside)

"I get to play a variety of instruments, and I can learn new stuff," he said.

"I've played bass drum, snare drum, drum kit, xylophone, glockenspiel, claves, tambourine."

'Happiness on a plate'

Monto State School principal Troy Jenkins said finding someone with both instrumental skills and a passion for teaching was a unique challenge — especially in a regional area.

Troy Jenkins says the program helps fill a gap in the regional town. (ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside)

"We had issues around getting staff members to facilitate the program, so for a small period of time we went to a distance ed [education] model," he said.

Mr Jenkins said Ms Greenfield's teaching was a huge boost to the school community.

"Our kids don't have a music teacher just down the road that they can access privately," he said.

"[Now] they're able to learn an instrument of their choice, but they're also able to participate in that band element and become immersed in that arts culture."

For Ms Greenfield, seeing her students succeed is "just happiness on a plate".

"Once they get it, it is just like jumping for joy. That is the best part of my career," she said.

" It's the biggest joy that you will ever see. Their faces just light up. "

Tina Greenfield also conducts band practice. (ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside)

Their success reflects Ms Greenfield's own journey, from shy child to confident teacher.

"I wouldn't have a conversation with someone unless I had my instrument in my hand and my instrument was my safety net," she said.

"I would never be comfortable sitting down and talking in front of people until it came to playing an instrument — and I could perform in front of everyone.

" I found my confidence through music. "

title: Aussie quick ruled out for remainder of Ashes in blow to bowling attack
text:
Australian fast bowler Josh Hazlewood has been ruled out of the remainder of the Ashes series amid hamstring and Achilles tendon injuries.

Injuries have thwarted the reliable right-arm quick in recent years and had forced him to watch from afar as Australia took a 2-0 series lead at the Gabba last week.

Hazlewood had been expected to play some part in the summer until a fresh Achilles issue clouded his availability last week and prevented him from reuniting with the squad in Brisbane.

Coach Andrew McDonald today confirmed he would miss the remainder of the series.

Australia is out for Ashes domination The snarl on Steve Smith's face proves conclusively that Australia doesn't just want to beat the English in this Ashes series. It wants to break them.

"He will be out of the series and his preparation will then shift towards the [2026 T20] World Cup, which is an incredibly important campaign for us but unfortunately, Josh won't be a part of the Ashes," McDonald said.

"It's really flat for him. A couple of setbacks we didn't see coming. We thought he'd play a huge part in the series. We really feel for him that he won't get that opportunity."

It comes after Hazlewood missed the entire Test tour of Sri Lanka earlier this year and played only two of a possible five Tests in last summer's home series against India.

Hazlewood's absence will likely mean Scott Boland, or possibly Michael Neser, keeps his spot in the XI for the third Test and beyond.

Boland has been the leading understudy for the pace-bowling cartel in recent years but Neser is coming off a five-wicket haul that helped secure victory at the Gabba.

McDonald flagged captain Pat Cummins' return from a back injury is likely to be the only change to Australia's squad for Adelaide, with Brendan Doggett expected to make way.

Confirmation of the 15-player squad is expected on Wednesday, with batter Usman Khawaja set to feature on return from his back injury.

Loading...

Despite Mitchell Starc's heavy workloads with bat and ball, Australia is expected to play a full-strength bowling attack given a chance to secure a series victory.

Players will have had nine full days off in between the end of the Gabba Test and the toss in Adelaide.

"We wouldn't be thinking about someone needing a rest there, it's probably more so in Test match four and five," McDonald said.

McDonald says there's nothing to patch up with Lyon

Nathan Lyon is expected to play a significant role in the attack after bowling only two overs in the first Test and being dropped for the second.

The veteran off-spinner has taken more Test wickets at Adelaide Oval than any other ground in world cricket.

"I'll make this a headline: We still do value spin," said McDonald, after part-timer Travis Head bowled Australia's only over of spin in Brisbane.

"That's the first game Nathan's missed in Australia for a long time. Has his impact been as great as previous seasons with the surfaces that we're playing on? Potentially not.

"(But) I think Nathan's going to have an incredibly huge impact in the last three Test matches if you look to what he did at the MCG last year.

"When the surface became benign day three onwards, he was able to navigate through a hole."

McDonald insisted there was nothing to patch up with Lyon, who told the Seven Network he was "absolutely filthy" about being dropped for the Gabba Test in favour of Neser.

"I don't think 'patch up' are the right words, that's probably a little bit of an overreaction," McDonald said.

"We just value different things in the pink-ball game and unfortunately that meant that Nathan had to squeeze (out), that's nothing to do with his skill set.

"For him to be disappointed, I understand that, I get that. I'd be disappointed if he wasn't disappointed."

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP

title: Canadian traditional owners fear Australian-style LNG development
text:
As hereditary chief Na'Moks is driven around Western Australia's Burrup Peninsula, the starkness of the infrastructure stands out in the Murujuga National Park.

A high chief of the Wet'suwet'en nation, he travelled from British Columbia's snowy mountain ranges to see what the West Australian government claimed was successful coexistence between industry and ancient Aboriginal heritage.

"All I see is people being ignored," he said.

Woodside Energy has processed the fossil fuel at two liquefied natural gas (LNG) plants on the peninsula, known by traditional owners as Murujuga, for 40 years, and has permission to do so for another 45.

At Murujuga, the gas plant sits a stone's throw from World Heritage-listed Aboriginal rock art. (ABC News: Chris Lewis)

Its operations are opposed by environmentalists and some traditional owners, who worry about its proximity to the oldest collection of rock art on Earth, recently inscribed into UNESCO's World Heritage List.

"[It's] the same type of path Canada's putting itself on where the dollar becomes more important than the human," Chief Na'Moks said.

Woodside and the West Australian government maintain there is no conclusive evidence about what impact industrial emissions are having on the Murujuga rock engravings.

Canadian govt backing LNG

Canada is only now starting to develop an LNG export industry, targeting the large volumes of shale gas contained within British Columbia's Montney formation.

But like in Australia, gas development has divided the region's traditional owners.

"Over the last 25 years in our homelands we have fended off upwards of 17 pipeline proposals and projects … until around 2019 and 2020," Gitxsan nation man Gwii Lok'im Gibuu Jesse Stoeppler said.

Chief Na'Moks was taken to the Karratha Gas Plant by Raelene Cooper. (ABC News: Charlie Mclean)

That project was Shell's LNG Canada facility, which shipped its first cargo in June.

Now a second LNG facility is being proposed for British Columbia, called Ksi Lisims.

It is being driven by a consortium of gas companies — including Woodside — and the Nisga'a Nation, which owns the coastal lands where the facility would be built.

Its proponents say it will bring social benefits and jobs to Indigenous Nations and other nearby communities.

But a 900-kilometre pipeline would need to be built to bring the gas in, slicing through other Indigenous nations' lands, including Mr Stoeppler's, who have not consented to the project.

'Dangerous' times

The Canadian government is desperate to boost the economy with more mining and infrastructure projects as the country continues to wrestle with the Trump administration's unpredictable tariff policies.

Ksi Lisims was recently referred to the Major Projects Office, a new department created to speed up approvals for projects deemed to be of national interest.

The idea mirrors the West Australian Labor government's State Development Bill, which Premier Roger Cook wants passed through parliament before the end of the year.

The premier has made no secret of his desire to cut red tape for industry, telling a recent audience of business leaders he had "a little bit of industrial FOMO".

"An obsession with big shiny job-creating projects, an insatiable desire for even faster approvals," Mr Cook said.

Gwii Lok'im Gibuu Jesse Stoeppler has been fending off gas developments slated for his homelands for years. (ABC News: Charlie Mclean)

Mr Stoeppler said he believed it was a dangerous time for the rights of Indigenous peoples across the western world.

"It is dangerous when elected bodies of government seemingly create interest or appetite where there is none on a local landscape," he said.

" What I'm seeing here with some of these projects is usually they come at the cost of Indigenous people and I take big issue with that. "

Murujuga traditional custodian Raelene Cooper, who guided chief Na'Moks and Mr Stoeppler around Murujuga, said she was saddened to see other traditional owners go through the same ordeal as her people.

Raelene Cooper has campaigned against industrial development at Murujuga. (ABC News: Charlie Mclean)

"We shared the very same stories, you know, of the concerns, the betrayal from our governments," she said.

"Those individuals who are supposed to be speaking on behalf of us are basically opening the door and bringing us to the slaughter."

A final investment decision for the Ksi Lisims project is expected early next year.

Long-term coexistence

A Woodside spokesperson said the company had operated on Murujuga for more than 40 years and took its commitment to managing and protecting cultural heritage in the area seriously.

"Our support for World Heritage listing of the Burrup Peninsula reflects the successful and long-term coexistence of heritage and industry," the spokesperson said.

"We actively engage with traditional custodians on the management of cultural heritage at our sites, including through heritage surveys, annual audits of heritage places and on-country visits.

"In consultation with traditional custodians, we develop and implement cultural heritage management plans to ensure the heritage values of the area are protected as far as practicable and in line with the requirements of applicable approvals and relevant laws.

"We believe long-term coexistence between cultural heritage and industry is possible when guided by credible science, traditional custodian leadership and genuine collaboration."

title: TPG Telecom links second death to Triple Zero failure
text:
TPG says a second death may be linked to a customer being unable to contact Triple Zero (000), as telco bosses face a Senate hearing in Canberra.

TPG Telecom chief executive Iñaki Berroeta revealed another possible death linked to a customer's inability to call Triple Zero on their Samsung mobile phone.

It follows the death of a TPG customer in Sydney in November, after outdated software blocked a Samsung phone from making Triple Zero calls.

On Tuesday, Mr Berroeta told the parliamentary hearing that another incident occurred on September 24, at Wentworth Falls in NSW's Blue Mountains, and TPG was made aware of it on Monday of this week when informed by Telstra.

"What we know … is … the customer was calling Triple Zero on that device, it did not work, the device was not compatible with the 4G calling emergency service," he said.

"And then five minutes later, that device was able to reach emergency services through an alternative means."

The alternative means was believed to be the National Relay Service, a 1800 number.

"Yesterday we were told that the call might have been made in connection to someone who has passed away," Mr Berroeta said.

In November, TPG confirmed a customer in Sydney had died after a mobile phone could not make Triple Zero calls.

At the time, the telco said early investigations indicated the failed calls were due to a Samsung device operating on software that was not compatible with making Triple Zero calls on the network.

Iñaki Berroeta says he was informed of a second death linked to a Triple Zero failure on Monday. (AAP: Paul Miller)

TPG operates the Vodafone brand, alongside internet providers TPG and iiNet.

'We don't blame the end user at all here'

Mr Berroeta told the Senate hearing TPG had identified tens of thousands of mobile phones that would need software updates in order to make emergency calls, which now requires 4G technology.

When asked why the necessary software updates were not automatic, Mr Berroeta said they were, but "it requires the customer to accept".

"We don't blame the end user at all here," Mr Berroeta later said.

Some Samsung phones unable to make triple-0 calls Some Samsung mobile phone users may be unable to call triple-0 in an emergency after Telstra announced testing had revealed more than 70 models were not connecting correctly.

TPG has sent messages via text, email and calls to customers whose devices need to be updated in order to access Triple Zero.

Mr Berroeta confirmed that included the customers whose deaths, in September and November, were believed to be linked to the telco.

Additionally, thousands of customers have phones that would never be able to make emergency calls via 4G and needed to be replaced in order to connect to Triple Zero.

Customers have been warned their phones will be blocked by TPG if they do not take action, while thousands of older models have already been blocked.

The ABC revealed in October that mobile phone testing by Telstra had identified more than 70 Samsung models that were unable to call Triple Zero on the Vodafone network when the Telstra and Optus networks were unavailable.

"Good customer relations would be to give these people a new phone now," Greens senator Sarah Hanson-Young put to Mr Berroeta.

"You're a big company, you make massive profits, making sure your customers have access to have a phone that can call Triple Zero should be a priority."

"It is a priority for us," Mr Berroeta replied. He told the hearing that around 500 customers had taken up the offer to replace their phones.

Executives from Nokia, Ericsson, Telstra, Samsung and consumer advocacy groups will also face questions at the hearings in Canberra.

The telcos have faced scrutiny in recent months after several deaths were linked to a widespread Optus outage in September, which revealed shocking failings across the sector.

title: FIFA confirms all 2026 World Cup games will include two water breaks
text:
FIFA says it will include three-minute hydration breaks in each half of every game at next year's World Cup, not just those played in hot weather.

The referee will stop the game 22 minutes into each half for players to take drinks, regardless of the temperature, the host country — the United States, Canada or Mexico — or whether the stadium has a roof and air conditioning.

The change may also be a hit with broadcasters, since it makes the game schedule more predictable and opens up more opportunities for advertisements.

FIFA said it was first announced when the governing body's chief tournament officer for the 2026 World Cup, Manolo Zubiria, attended a meeting with broadcasters.

Socceroos based on west coast for World Cup Australia's North American west coast adventure at the World Cup is confirmed, with matches in Vancouver, Seattle and Santa Clara in California.

He indicated that referees may have some flexibility if there was a stoppage shortly before the 22-minute mark for an injury.

"This will be addressed on the spot with the referee," Zubiria said.

FIFA said the move was a "streamlined and simplified version" of an earlier practice of having breaks after 30 minutes over a certain temperature threshold, once set at 32 degrees Celsius on the wet bulb global temperature system.

The change comes after heat and humidity affected players during some games at this year's Club World Cup in the US.

At that tournament, FIFA reacted by lowering the threshold for cooling or water breaks and also placing more water and towels around the edge of the field.

Heat has long been an issue at major soccer tournaments. Amid concerns ahead of the 2014 World Cup, a Brazilian court ordered FIFA to make its recommended breaks mandatory or face fines.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AP

title: Isolated families furious over WA's regional flight cap changes
text:
Regional West Australians say the government's increased airfare caps during peak flight periods will unfairly isolate them.

The state government introduced a scheme in 2022 that capped fares for one-way trips to Perth within 1,000 kilometres at $199, and $299 for flights longer than that distance.

Prior to the scheme, regional residents — particularly in the Pilbara and Kimberley — would often pay more than $1,000 for one-way trips to Perth.

But from July 1 next year, the capped fares will increase during "high-demand" periods, and remain the same for "low-demand" periods.

During high-demand periods, one-way flights to airports less than 1,000 kilometres from Perth will be capped at $265, while those further away will increase to $385.

Families 'locked out'

The $385 cost per flight during peak periods will affect those in WA's northern regional towns, including Karratha, Broome, Exmouth, Kununurra, Newman, Paraburdoo and Port Hedland.

Karratha mother of three Kirsty Freeman said busy periods such as school holidays were the only time her family could visit her Adelaide-based family and friends.

Kirsty and Karl Freeman have children who have appointments in Perth. (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

The raised peak-period cap will see her family pay an extra $860 to fly to and from Perth, with a total cost of $3,850.

"My friends and family can't afford to come and visit us up here," Ms Freeman said.

'We're basically isolated in this town."

She said the changes meant her family would now drive 16 hours to the city to catch a flight to Adelaide.

"It's really scary for us financially," Ms Freeman said.

She said her teenage children needed braces, which could only be fitted and removed in Perth.

A rally opposing increases to subsidised regional airfares was held in Karratha last month. (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

WA's Patient Assisted Travel Scheme (PATS) subsidises the costs of accessing medical services that are not available locally, but allied health and dental treatments are not included in the scheme.

"Just having the procedure is expensive, but then adding on flights and accommodation to get those things done as well is a little bit daunting," Ms Freeman said.

"People think because we're in a mining town that we're all just made of money, and that's definitely not how it is."

Jo Camilleri says families with children at boarding schools will be affected. (Supplied)

Concerns for boarders

Kimberley parent and Isolated Children's Parents' Association member Jo Camilleri said the changes were "worrying", especially for students who were studying away from home.

"It's during the peak season we need the cap more," she said.

"It's during school holidays that kids are flying home and that's why we really needed it in the first place.

"If anything, you'd hope the cap was in place for [busy periods] rather than the reverse."

Ms Camilleri was concerned the price changes would most affect families living in remote towns like Halls Creek and Fitzroy Crossing, who also have to travel long distances just to get to an airport.

"It just gets further and further out of reach for families … the more remote people get, the more difficult this becomes," she said.

Kim Simpson says the cap increase is "garbage". (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

Kim Simpson organised a petition against increased subsidised fare caps and has so far collected more than 6,000 signatures.

She described the changes as "garbage".

She said while it was "fantastic" the cap was kept, the subsidised flights were already too expensive.

"I've flown to Perth three times in the past month and I've spent close to $3,000," she said.

"We are still going to keep on with the petition … we can still fight for these cheaper fares," she said.

High-demand period remains vague

Premier Roger Cook said the cap increase was necessary to keep the scheme sustainable and to meet the difference between airline prices in peak periods.

Roger Cook says the government and airlines will decide what is considered a "peak period". (ABC Pilbara: Kimberley Putland)

"We want to reward those people who are looking to travel in times of low demand," he said.

"But for last-minute bookings or for high peak demands, the subsidy isn't as high."

"This is better than pre-2022, when they [regional families] would have paid literally thousands."

Deciding what is considered "peak period" will be an arrangement between the government and the airlines, he said.

'We will work closely with airlines to ensure that they bring the right approach, the right attitude to this," Mr Cook said.

The state government said that for the first time, airlines could choose to offer capped fares that were cheaper than the set maximums.

Mr Cook said the scheme would continue until June 2031 before it would be reviewed again.

title: 'Finally rocked up': Weatherald and Stokes caught up in Ashes sledging
text:
Ben Stokes and Jake Weatherald have been caught sledging each other during the heated conclusion of the second Ashes Test in Brisbane.

The verbal back and forth came after English quick Jofra Archer and Australian batting star Steve Smith traded barbs as Australia went 2-0 up in the five Test Ashes series.

With only a handful of runs to make to claim victory, Smith went for his shots to end the match quickly, scoring 23 runs from just nine balls.

Smith's cavalier attitude earned an odd rebuke from Archer, who had struggled with the pink ball throughout the Test.

"You like to play shots when there's not much on the scoreboard," Archer, who is yet to dimiss Smith in a Test, said.

"You bowl fast when there's nothing going on, champion," Smith replied, after Archer bowled his fastest spell of the tour so far.

After the incident, Archer briefly turned his attention to Weatherald at the other end but it wasn't clear if he said anything to the rookie opener.

"Spit it out if you're going to say something," Weatherald appeared to say to Archer.

Loading...

"Finally rocked up."

Weatherald's response caught the attention of English skipper Stokes, who referenced the runs the newcomer made in the first innings having struggled in the first Test in Perth.

"You got 70 and started chatting," Stokes said.

"I was only saying something because you were saying something now," Weatherald responded.

Australia is out for Ashes domination The snarl on Steve Smith's face proves conclusively that Australia doesn't just want to beat the English in this Ashes series. It wants to break them.

"I say it with a smile my face though, Jake," Stokes said.

While sledging is a common part of the game, the heated end to the Brisbane Test is bound to create tension ahead of the start of the third Test in Adelaide on December 17.

The English squad has travelled to Noosa for a break before the third Test, as England's second team lost badly to Australia A at Allan Border Field in Brisbane, highlighting the nation's current lack of depth.

"I actually felt like we over-prepared to be honest," McCullum said after the second Test.

"I think sometimes when you're in the heat of the battle, as we all know, sometimes the most important thing is to feel a bit fresh."

title: Chef highlights alternative fish species ahead of demersal ban
text:
The West Australian food ambassador says the fishing industry should take the lead on education as consumers search for local alternatives in the wake of major changes to fishing rules.

Last week the WA government announced a plan to slash demersal catch limits and shut down some fisheries to save species on the brink of extinction.

That was followed by warnings from fishers and the food service industry that the new rules could make it harder for the public to source locally caught fish or find them on restaurant menus.

Dhufish will be difficult to find at restaurants from next month. (ABC News: Chris Lewis)

Affordable, healthy alternatives

Many chefs and cooks across the state will be rethinking their shopping lists and menus before the ban comes into effect later this month.

What are demersal fish? Demersal scalefish are long-living, slow-growing fish species that live and feed near the seabed. Popular demersal fish in WA waters include dhufish, pink snapper and red emperor.

Chef Don Hancey, who has been appointed WA's food ambassador to promote local produce, said he felt for the fishers impacted by the changes, particularly generational family businesses.

He suggested those planning new menus consider the "underutilised species" found in WA waters.

"We've got beautiful herring, we've got mullet, we've got the sardines from Freo and down south, we've also got the Australian salmon," Mr Hancey said.

"So there's great opportunities to make something simple, like fish cakes, that are super affordable.

"There are alternatives, but there needs to be a push now to educate people that using these underutilised species is not only good for the pocket, but good for your health."

Mr Hancey believes Australian salmon is an "under-utilised" species. (Supplied: Louise FitzRoy)

Industry-led showcase

Mr Hancey anticipated it would take time for the public to change culinary habits, but believed industry showcases could expedite the process.

"It needs WAFIC [Western Australian Fishing Industry Council] and other organisations like FRDC [Fisheries Research and Development Corporation] to really start showcasing these species to the general public and chefs to increase their knowledge," he said.

Mr Hancey said a herring dish at his former restaurant in Yallingup had been a popular addition to the menu.

"One of the biggest sellers on the breakfast menu was herring, pan-fried, lots of lemon juice, little bit of butter, and some chopped parsley served on a sourdough toast," he said.

" It's not only tasty and economical, but it is so, so healthy for you. "

As a pelagic species of fish, herring are unaffected by the rule changes. (Supplied: Shannon Conway)

Adapting with consumer tastes

Albany commercial fisher Tony Westerberg said he was in "disbelief" when he heard of the changes that would affect his industry peers.

"Fish stocks are ailing but what they've done is ridiculous," he said.

Mr Westerberg's business is focused on pelagic species — catching sardines, herring and salmon.

Commercial fisherman and seafood wholesaler Tony Westerberg expects demand will change. (ABC Great Southern: Georgia Hargreaves)

He said one challenge with herring was an aversion to "strong" flavours among younger consumers.

"It's normally fairly strong-tasting and not many younger people like the oiliness of the fish," Mr Westerberg said.

"So we've done the herring in a way which is deep skinning, and there's no traditional herring flavour … it's still got all the goodness in there."

He expects demand to slowly shift after the changes come into effect on December 16.

title: 'How the hell does this happen?' Double skiing gold for 'beach nation' Aussies
text:
Australia's moguls skiers have got their Winter Olympic season up and running with a superb double gold in the FIS World Cup event in Ruka, Finland.

Defending Olympic champion Jakara Anthony and 2018 Olympic silver medallist Matt Graham both claimed victories on the Battery Course in the Finnish resort on Monday night.

It is Anthony's first World Cup gold in 12 months after missing most of last season with a broken collar bone.

"It's pretty special," she told FIS.com.

"It's probably nearly a year to the day of getting injured. I've been out since then, so this is a pretty special one."

Anthony made the final of the season opener in tough, icy conditions the day prior after qualifying third, but was unable to complete her run, perhaps a little rusty after watching from afar for the past 12 months.

"Yesterday was a bummer," she said.

"I just didn't quite nail that last one.

"To get redemption tonight is pretty special. It's been a while since I skied a comp, so I had to remember that and make those adjustments tonight."

American pair Olivia Giaccio and last year's World Cup winner Jaelen Kauf claimed the other two podium positions.

The victory is the 27-year-old's 24th World Cup gold.

Australians Charlotte Wilson (13th) and Emma Bosco (20th) also competed.

Meanwhile, Graham claimed his first victory in a World Cup since Deer Valley in the 2022/23 season, nailing a superb run as last skier to compete.

"It's good to be putting down really good runs. The course was challenging, but really fun, and I'm just enjoying it," he said.

"To get a double gold with Jakara — it's massive. We're not a skiing nation. We're a beach nation, so how the hell does this happen?"

Fellow Australian Harvey Jackson (18th) also competed, with Cooper Woods and George Murphy both failing to complete the course in what remained tough conditions.

Graham, 31, has had a superb start to the season, claiming fourth place in the season opener on the same course on Sunday.

It is the third time in history that Australia has claimed gold medals in both men's and women's events on the same day.

Veteran skier Graham has been a part of all three.

There was disappointment for the aerial skiers though, with Australia missing having a skier on the podium for the first time in a World Cup event since January 2023.

Airleigh Frigo (6th), Laura Peel (10th), Danielle Scott (13th) and Abbey Willcox (14th) all competed in the women's event, with Riley Flanagan (19th) in the men's.

The next two moguls events on the calendar in Sweden and Georgia have been cancelled, so the moguls skiers will take a break and resume competition in the new year at Val Saint-Come in Canada.

The Winter Olympic Games competition gets underway in Livigno on February 10.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

title: Australian carols that are perfect for celebrating Christmas in the sun
text:
Are you stuck listening to Let It Snow while figuring out how to crank your aircon?

Most Australians can't have chestnuts roasting on an open fire because there's usually a fire ban in December.

"Even my favourite carol line of all time, 'let steeple bells be swungen' is a little off for an Aussie summer," says Vanessa Hughes, the presenter of ABC Classic Drive.

Christmas Crackers Turn up the volume for the holiday season with a curated selection of Christmas favourites from ABC Classic.

"Let pints in pubs be drunken" seems more apt for Christmas here," she says.

But fear not.

From Carol of the Birds to Christmas in the Sun, Australian composers have been coming up with seasonally appropriate Christmas carols for decades.

"This year's Classic Choir song, Christmas in the Sun, perfectly captures our antipodean holiday vibes," Hughes says.

These carols won't give you brain freeze from dreaming of a white Christmas.

Classic Australian Christmas carols

If you've heard any Australian Christmas carols or sung them at school, there's a good chance they're by William G James.

He composed three books of Australian Christmas carols.

One of James's most famous carols is Carol of the Birds, sometimes called Orana based on the words of the chorus.

James had the Australian answer to Northern Hemisphere carols.

The Three Drovers, the Australian stand-in for shepherds, ride across the plain when the air is thick with summer heat and smoke is on the yellow moon.

Talking about Australian sky, The Silver Star, which has a lovely treble solo, is another famous tune by James.

Loading...

James was a longtime music director at the ABC.

Many of his tunes were published during his tenure and found their way into songbooks for primary schools in the 50s and 60s.

A summer celebration

More recently, ABC Classic has been expanding Australian Christmas carol collections with the Classic Choir songbook.

If you grew up here, or have lived in Australia for some time, you know that Christmas falls in the summer.

We mark the season of sunshine by trying to stay cool, spending time with family and eating.

Many Australian Christmas carols immortalise these moments.

In 2020, when the COVID-19 lockdowns restricted our ability to sing or be with our loved ones, ABC Classic launched the virtual Classic Choir.

Deborah Cheetham Fraillon wrote Christmas With You, and 1,500 people submitted videos of themselves singing the song.

Loading...

In 2023, Gardening Australia host Clarence Slockee wrote new words for the classic, Oh Christmas Tree, honouring First Nations languages around Australia.

This Australian take of Oh Christmas Tree (Yerrbill with Clarence), was arranged by Joseph Twist.

Loading...

Other carols include Katie Noonan's All is Love, Elena Kats-Chernin's quintessential Summer Together and another addition from Cheetham Fraillon: The Christmas Card.

After launching five successful carols, the Classic Choir project wraps up in 2025 with Joseph Twist's brand new carol: Christmas in the Sun.

The carol will be premiered on December 14 by the Sydney Philharmonia Choirs at the Sydney Opera House, and broadcast live on ABC Classic at 2pm.

Aussie Christmas in pop culture

Over the years, Australian artists have written some Christmas hits which now reside deep in our collective psyche.

Comedy duo Colin Buchanan and Greg Champion, performing as Bucko & Champs, have adapted familiar Christmas jingles in an Australian context.

Most people would probably assign ultimate Christmas classic status to Paul Kelly's 1996 ballad How To Make Gravy, about a man called Joe who writes a letter home from prison.

Loading...

The song became a movie in 2024, and earlier this year Kelly released Rita Wrote a Letter, which details what happens when Joe is released.

Other artists might not be as dramatic as Joe's family but, as we all know, Christmas can be difficult for some.

Stella Donnelly's Seasons Greetings explores this family tension when an estranged relative turns up.

The history of the estrangement is first revealed through what they did with the gravy, and from there tension mounted until insults are hurled.

Australians love our summertime Christmas with its glorious sunshine, surf and stars.

Christine Anu's Island Christmas captures all of these tropical beauties with a powerful love letter filled with colours, laughter and music.

title: Graham Richardson state funeral LIVE updates: Prime minister delivers eulogy as Labor heavyweights farewell late political kingmaker
text:
“Those who knew Dad, no matter their background, shared a deep admiration for his wit, humour, principles and policy achievements,” Graham Richardson’s son D’Arcy, who just finished his HSC, has told those gathered.

“Mum and I had the immense honour of being invited by the Prime Minister and the Speaker of the House to sit on the floor of Parliament to hear the testimonies from his condolence motion during Parliament’s last sitting week.

Amanda and D’Arcy Richardson speak. Credit: James Brickwood

“What struck me most was the number of MPs who came up to talk about the ways dad helped them in their careers. I had no idea the different ways dad touched those in Parliament throughout their lives, contributing to the great work they’re doing representing their communities.”

He said being a great dad was Richardson’s greatest legacy.

While several speakers spoke highly of D’Arcy, there has been scant mention of Richardson’s two children from his previous marriage to Cheryl Gardner, Matthew and Kate.

title: ‘I saw my patient fly to the ceiling’: GP caught up in Niddrie fatal crash vows to rebuild
text:
Dr Rafid Hamdan was consulting a patient - one of hundreds, if not thousands, in his decades-long career - when everything changed.

He turned briefly to his computer, and then a huge explosion filled the room.

Geraldine Maguire, right, lays a floral tribute at the Niddrie practice where a fatal car crash occurred on Monday, December 8. Credit: Eddie Jim

“I heard my receptionist scream, and suddenly I just saw my patient fly to the ceiling,” he said.

“Then everything collapsed in the room.”

title: Wells left car waiting for hours at NRL grand final, costing more than $1200
text:
Farrell charges for hundreds of family flights Farrell charged taxpayers more than $116,000 for family travel since 2022, according to Independent Parliamentary Expenses Authority data. This includes flying a family member to Uluru, where he had been gifted tickets to a Wintjiri Wiru Sunset Dinner in August 2024. The flights that coincided with the dinner cost $2093.65 for a return trip from Adelaide to Uluru via Sydney. Other family travel matched dates that Farrell had been gifted tickets, including return flights for a family member to Sydney, costing $1385.21, at the same time as opera La Boheme at the Sydney Opera House. Farrell had been given a double pass and hospitality, according to his register of interests. Minister for Trade and Tourism, and Special Minister of State Don Farrell. Credit: Alex Ellinghausen Farrell defended the expenses, saying they were within the guidelines and that the rules allowed for carers and single parents to become politicians.

“The family reunion provisions are an important feature of our framework, allowing a diverse range of members and senators to represent their communities in our nation’s parliament,” he said in a statement.



“Our parliament would be a lesser place if it weren’t for the mechanisms that allow young mothers, single parents, those with families, and those with caring responsibilities to serve as elected members.” Loading Minister for Home Affairs Tony Burke, in 2020, repaid the cost of flights for his family to join him on a trip to Uluru in 2012 because, while within the rules, he said the expenses “did not meet community expectations”. Under the family reunion rules, federal MPs are allowed up to three return business class flights per year for family members flying between the MP’s home base and a city other than Canberra, and the value of nine business class flights to Canberra, though there is some flexibility to the rules that allows ministers to claim more. Coalition MP calls for Wells to resign as minister

Wells has defended the flights and expenses as within the rules, but has endured ongoing criticism for the nature of her trips and a lack of judgment in flying her children and husband to Thredbo for a ski trip, and billing taxpayers thousands to fly her husband to three AFL grand finals and two Boxing Day Test matches. On most occasions, her husband flew home to Brisbane on the same day. Wells’ expenses first came under scrutiny last Wednesday when it was revealed in an answer to a Senate estimates committee that she billed taxpayers almost $100,000 to fly herself, a staffer and a public servant to New York in September for the United Nations General Assembly. Nationals senator Matt Canavan on Tuesday called for Wells to resign because though she may not have broken any rules, there was a pattern of misjudgment that did not meet community expectations. Family reunion travel rules The obligations of MPs when determining whether they can claim family reunion expenses. Dominant purpose: Under family reunion rules, an MP’s family can accompany or join them at Commonwealth expense while they are conducting parliamentary business. Travel must be for the “dominant purpose” of facilitating the family life of the parliamentarian.

Under family reunion rules, an MP’s family can accompany or join them at Commonwealth expense while they are conducting parliamentary business. Travel must be for the “dominant purpose” of facilitating the family life of the parliamentarian. Value for money: MPs are required to use public resources for parliamentary business in a way that achieves value for money. MPs can have family members travel to Canberra under a cost-based limit per year, and can claim up to three return business-class airfares for family to travel elsewhere in Australia.

MPs are required to use public resources for parliamentary business in a way that achieves value for money. MPs can have family members travel to Canberra under a cost-based limit per year, and can claim up to three return business-class airfares for family to travel elsewhere in Australia. Good faith: MPs need to act ethically and in good faith when using, or accounting for, public resources. They must not seek to disguise personal or commercial business as parliamentary business.

MPs need to act ethically and in good faith when using, or accounting for, public resources. They must not seek to disguise personal or commercial business as parliamentary business. Personal responsibility and accountability: An MP is personally responsible and accountable for their use of public resources and should consider how the public would perceive their use of these resources.

An MP is personally responsible and accountable for their use of public resources and should consider how the public would perceive their use of these resources. Conditions: An MP must not make a claim, or incur an expense, in relation to a public resource if they have not met all of the conditions for its provision. “I think there’s too many yellow cards here from Anika Wells. I think she needs to be shown a red,” he told Sky News.

Canavan said getting a Comcar to wait seven hours at the tennis was “ridiculous”, and other ministers had been forced out of parliamentary positions for less, including former Speaker Bronwyn Bishop and Opposition Leader Sussan Ley. “You’re spending other people’s money, not your own. So I don’t think Anika Wells, as a minister of the crown, has shown any care and diligence here to make sure her spending ... meets that value for money test,” Canavan said. “The question now is to the prime minister, what standards do you have? Do you apply any discipline to your ministers to pay a price if they’re not seen to be spending money in a value sense?” This masthead revealed on Monday that Wells charged taxpayers almost $1000 to have a government-funded Comcar wait seven hours for her while she attended the Australian Open tennis final in January 2023, and the Australian Financial Review reported on Tuesday she claimed another $765 for a chauffeur-driven car while attending the Magic Millions Race Day on the Gold Coast in January 2024. Coalition figures have challenged the government’s response, saying the travel was outside what Australians expect.

“Whether things are in the guidelines or not, it’s always up to the individual parliamentarian to justify his or her expenses. That’s always been the case,” shadow treasurer Ted O’Brien told ABC Radio National. Loading He called the judgment of Wells and the prime minister into question for claiming the expenses were appropriate during a cost-of-living crisis. “What we see here is the prime minister defending a minister who is spending money that is hard to justify in the public eye,” O’Brien said. “Saying that this level of spending is fine – that goes to his judgment.”
